data.body: See discussion in #12726.

data.title: Renderer Improvements
data.body:
As discussed on the IRC channel, these are some ideas for improving the renderer, I'm quite illiterate when it comes to programming so I don't know how much work any of these would be, as such I make no requests, but these are listed for posterity's sake. 

I would love to hear feedback from the devs if any of these are achievable during the current reworking the renderer is getting. I would also be interested in learning to code at some point to implement some of these.

1. Alpha channel
A separate alpha channel would allow for anti-aliasing, pre-rendered motion blur (rotors, explosions), true transparency (fire, explosions, flares, glows etc), overlay animations (beach waves, wind). Perhaps this could also be utilized to somehow make terrain more interesting through a secondary terrain layer that could be essentially brushed over the base tiles. I personally believe this is has the most use out of all the points.

2. Normals channel
The combination of a normals, depth and alpha with dynamic lighting, which I assume is happening for TS, would allow for relighting of objects in game taking into consideration the objects' shapes, I'm not sure how computationally expensive that is however, I think that's the most ambitious point, with probably the least return for most projects, although it would be very cool to see games with explosions/muzzles that affect their surroundings and Nomad Galaxy with planets that are lit ingame by the stars.

3. Different formats support
Shps and Westwood PALs are a PITA to work with, the tools are limited, broken and not intuitive. I can see some modders migrating from TS/RA2 to OpenRA once TS is implemented, but it's hard to imagine anyone outside of this community doing so with the current formats.
Whether this format is 8 or 32 bit doesn't matter much especially since we can use virtually limitless palettes . Although I'm sure some people would like to have more colors to work with.

4. Terrain Creation
This is a more complex point and I don't have a crystallized thought on this yet, but I would imagine there are better/easier ways to create terrain than fixed cell sizes. This was briefly touched upon in the IRC channel and sparked my interest. Any ideas would probably have to keep it friendly to the mapmakers themselves.
This is a quite interesting approach https://ppmforums.com/viewtopic.php?t=41860
And if it can be combined with alpha channels as "brushes"might even be more interesting, but I would love to hear if anyone has ideas.
Another example, of something completely different is Nomad Galaxy again, while the approach above could be useful, a background image or procedural generators could be even more powerful, especially when you combine that with alpha channels and parallax scrolling for different layers of space "objects".

Warman

data.title: OpenRA Manifest - Windows supported versions
data.body:
Closes #13243 (OS Version returns 10.0.* instead of 9.2.* on Win 10)

(Note: in the .manifest file is also commented setting dpiAware - Indicates that the application is DPI-aware and will not be automatically scaled by Windows at higher DPIs)

With the release of Windows 8.1, the behavior of the GetVersionEx API has changed in the value it will return for the operating system version. The value returned by the GetVersionEx function now depends on how the application is manifested.

Applications not manifested for Windows 8.1 or Windows 10 will return the Windows 8 OS version value (6.2). Once an application is manifested for a given operating system version, GetVersionEx will always return the version that the application is manifested for in future releases.

Manifesting the .exe for Windows 8.1 or Windows 10 will not have any impact when run on previous operating systems.

data.title: OS Version inconsistent on Windows 10
data.body:
Yesterday I did a fresh install of Windows 10 1703 and (immediately) a fresh install of OpenRA 20170421.

This version of Windows is 10.0.15063 but OpenRA detects it as 6.2.9200.

![real_windows_version](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25843400/25742559/47ff3286-3190-11e7-9a4a-90a54b4a4c90.jpg)

![openra_windows_version](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25843400/25742562/499f0c60-3190-11e7-89b3-bb5783d0f13d.jpg)

According to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Microsoft_Windows_versions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Microsoft_Windows_versions) NT 6.2.9200 is Windows 8.

Internet says people reported this bug in Windows 10 [https://www.google.com/search?q=windows+10+6.2.9200](https://www.google.com/search?q=windows+10+6.2.9200).

Commands like `ver`, `winver` or even `cmd` return the correct version number anyway.

ReturnOnIdle seems useless, because planes are ordered explicitly to return on "RetunToBase"(F key) or out of ammo, they don't return based on ReturnOnIdle trait. data.title: Selling structure (PP) doesn't always give Rifleman
data.body:
In case of an enemy engy capture, selling a structure to get a rifleman can save your MCV.

However, I figured out today that is seems to be random. I sold a first PP, getting only technicians, then realized it too late. Sold another PP, got low power, but lost my MCV nevertheless, killed the engy too late. 

Shouldn't there be no random factor in it ? It's double punishing to lose a building (maybe getting low power) and still risking to lose the MCV due to chance.

data.title: Unit ignoring movement commands until exiting from the tunnel.
data.body:
![2017-05-04_19-07-49](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9460838/25718466/1c3b136e-30fe-11e7-86b2-21dc8580b34f.gif)

Shown in the above gif, I'm sending a unit to the other side of the tunnel. Once the unit has entered the tunnel, I'm unable to send the unit back where he comes from. This is evident by the clicking animation on the cursor.

milestone.title: Tiberian Sun Public Alpha
milestone.description: An incomplete list of blockers for a public alpha release.

data.body: Also fixes TS wall and gate shapes.

data.title: Smarter warhead/projectile victim scans
data.body:
This makes 
- the two relevant warheads use the largest health radius for victim scans
- all blockable projectiles use the largest health radius of an actor with `IBlocksProjectilesInfo` for normal blocker scans
- bouncing `Bullet`s use the largest health radius for blocker scans
- `AreaBeam` the largest health radius for "ambient damage" victim scans

I decided to keep the fields around so this behavior can be overridden, but made the upgrade rule remove the (old) fields from yaml files, since under normal circumstances there won't be any need to use them.
Also renamed them to something more fitting, and split them into regular blocking and special-case properties for Bullet and AreaBeam.

Finally, since only people who either know what they're doing or just want to fool around will ever see the need to use these overrides, I dropped the lint rule entirely since those edge cases should be incredibly rare and don't justify the amount of work and changes necessary to make the lint rule work properly.
The only sensible reason to set custom values would be to deliberately set lower values to save performance, while deliberately accepting the side-effects, in which case lint warnings (let alone errors) would just be annoying anyway.

Supersedes #12609.

data.title: Different type of "cash\money"
data.body:
From what i understand there is only 1 type of currency, and all resource gathering is related to that.

For new mods that are going far from the basics of C&C logic (resource related at least) this could be a preventing factor for making these kinds of mods.

As we know the OpenRa engine aims to be a more wide and open base for more and new "games".

For example we want to add more requirements to build a castle, not only money but also stone, there are other examples like TS chemical missile.
In my case i wan't to add research points that are gathered via tech centers like an oil, in order to research new tech but prevent players doing so by the use of money.

So a unlimited type of different "money\cash" will be a good idea.

data.title: Anti virus false alarm (avast)
data.body:
Avast removes OpenRA.Game.exe and places it under the "virus chest"  this could be a problem with some one new to the game as a trusting issue and could also stop players from playing the game if they don't know how an anti virus work. 

This should be added as troubleshooting information, and maybe contact the anti virus company?

data.title: Unhardcode mod package loaders
data.body:
This updates #13171 with architectural fixes and addresses the other FileSystem hacks that were blocked on having mod-defined package loaders.

This breaks the cycling dependency between assemblies that define package loaders that contain assemblies that define package loaders that... by requiring all dlls to be loaded from a normal directory.  This then also fixes @abcdefg30's SharpDevelop problems.

This is already a monster of a PR, so i'm going to defer moving all the package loaders to the mod assemblies to a future PR.  I've done the D2K sound parser as a testcase, but moving any more would make it difficult to keep a clean git history while addressing any review comments.

The final commit shows that it is still possible to explicitly mount subdirectories inside zip files.

I strongly suggest reviewing this commit by commit, using the `?w=1` parameter to squash whitespace changes on the main package loader commits.

data.title: AI picks support power/superweapon targets without vision
data.body:
AI in both the Tiberium Dawn and Red Alert mods will use airstrikes, nukes, and ion cannons on targets they do not, and never had, vision of. This is exacerbated by the incredible power of the nuke, and the near-instantaneous effect of the airstrike.

Ideally the AI would try to scout for targets, or "guess" based on things like spawn location or buildings/units that they *have* seen before.
